question: where does the name loyola university come from
api_result: The name "Loyola University" is derived from Saint Ignatius of Loyola, who was the founder of the Society of Jesus, commonly known as the Jesuits. Saint Ignatius of Loyola was a Spanish Basque Catholic priest and theologian, who lived during the 16th century. He founded the Jesuit order in 1540, which was pivotal in the Counter-Reformation. Loyola University institutions, such as Loyola University Chicago, Loyola University Maryland, and Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles, among others, are Jesuit institutions of higher education that were named in his honor. These universities aim to promote the educational and spiritual vision of Saint Ignatius of Loyola.
